candidates.text: I used to think TypeScript was a pain until a JavaScript app crashed in production. With TypeScript, builds fail early and force fixes before users see anything. It doesn‚Äôt make apps perfect it just saves you from mistakes

Deployed to production on Friday at 5 PM. Worst mistake of my career.

Our React Native app crashed for 50,000+ users instantly. Payment processing down. Support tickets flooding in.

The database migration I pushed had a typo in the user authentication query. One missing character broke everything.

At 11 PM, debugging in panic mode, I realized the rollback was useless. The migration couldn‚Äôt be undone.

So I wrote a hotfix right in production. Fixed the query, manually checked 200+ user accounts, deployed again at 2 AM.

Never deploy on Fridays. But if you do, make sure you‚Äôve got a backup plan for your backup plan.

I "Accept All" in Cursor for a client project.

What followed: 40+ hours of debugging, an angry client call, and a hard lesson about AI coding.

Here's my new framework that actually works:
üßµ

Imagine: Your production app crashed. You noticed. The big fix took 10 minutes. But it's been an hour and your users are still complaining; because your app is still "compiling". All because it was written in Rust.

I once lost an entire workday (and a demo) because of ONE simple mistake.

Everything worked perfectly in staging...

But when we deployed to production, the app crashed immediately.

After hours of debugging, we found the culprit:

Our Docker image was installing dependencies from the raw requirements instead of the lock file.

This tiny difference meant we pulled slightly different versions of FastAPI and its sub-dependencies.

And that subtle mismatch was enough to bring the system down.

I learned a very important lesson that day...

When you install without the lock file, your environment becomes non-deterministic.

You might think everything‚Äôs the same, but dependency trees change silently underneath you.

The lock file exists for a reason: it‚Äôs your single source of truth for environment consistency.

If you skip it, you‚Äôre gambling with stability.

Here's what I do now:

‚Ä¢ Always install from the lock file instead of the raw dependency list
‚Ä¢ Pin versions explicitly and treat the lock file as part of the source code
‚Ä¢ Whether using Poetry, UV, or any other tool - enforce this in CI and Docker builds
 
If you've ever had an environment "mysteriously" break between builds... 
Check your lock file.

It may save you 24 hours (and your next demo)

P.S. Have you ever experienced this before?

One Lesson I Learned from Breaking Production

One line of code. That‚Äôs all it took to break my employer‚Äôs app in production.

I was feeling confident with Next.js, until I used the window object inside a server component. The app crashed instantly.

Confessions of a Spring Boot Developer: 'Our Tests Passed, but Production Broke!‚Äô'  üò± 

True story: A team had 90% test coverage, yet their app crashed on Day 1. 

Why? ¬† 

‚Üí They mocked external APIs with simplified responses that missed edge cases
‚Üí Their fast tests with an in-memory H2 database didn‚Äôt catch PostgreSQL JSONB quirks. ¬† 
‚Üí No one tested with real traffic spikes

Moral: Tests must mirror reality. What‚Äôs your 'tests lied to me' moment?

200 - OK
201 - Created
204 - No Content

400 - Bad Request
401 - Unauthorized
403 - Forbidden
404 - Not Found

500 - Internal Server Error
502 - Bad Gateway
503 - Service Unavailable

Was poking around dev forums for PloyCloud research.

All running MySQL/Postgres on a $5/month VPS. For production. With real users.

"‚ùå site down"

Watchdog:

"‚ùå site down ‚Äî 502 Bad Gateway. Origin server crashed. Restart your process, check /var/log/nginx/error.log first."

One of those saves you 2 hours of debugging at midnight.

https://t.co/GnVo6cb58z
@eldivine @VoiceOfTheEast The voice of the east website is down. Got a 502 nginx error. Can someone please fix this?

Every uptime monitor sends you this:

"üî¥ site down"

Cool. Thanks. Now what?

Watchdog sends you:

"502 Bad Gateway ‚Äî origin server crashed. Restart your process, check /var/log/nginx/error.log first."

That's the difference between panic and a plan.

https://t.co/GnVo6cb58z

candidates.text:
Everyone loves AI in movie trailers. Nobody loves the AWS bill after render.

Today‚Äôs Star Wars parody writes itself: public narrative = infinite Force power. Reality in the data center = finite GPU queues, expensive VRAM, and RAM bottlenecks that kill throughput.

Hype sells headlines. Infrastructure costs decide who survives.

Full breakdown: https://t.co/hP4C1xNOpI

#AI #VFX #GenAI #CloudComputing #Startups #filmmaking

Accidentally left console.log() in production.

It logged every user click for 6 months. 1.6TB of 'button clicked' messages.

AWS bill: $677 for CloudWatch storage.

What's your most expensive coding mistake?

The shortest code was from Claude. It was 15 lines. Looked elegant. Deployed it. 2 hours later, my entire AWS bill was $500. Turns out Claude's elegant code had an infinite loop spinning up expensive GPU instances. Copilot's 50line ugly code?Perfect. Never trusting elegant again.

@joedavinci_net @brankopetric00 ECS is not expensive in terms of overall AWS bill, but AWS as a whole *is* expensive and ECS definitely promotes more lock-in by simply not being as flexible so you have to go through more packaged services from AWS.

And AWS becomes hella expensive if your revenue isn't in USD

@pawel_lasek @brankopetric00 just checked the AWS bill for production systems, ECS is not even an item on there. total is thousands per month, but ECS is literally zero... only ECR about $20 because of storage.

Not saying there is anything wrong with k8s, just that ECS works and it is not at all expensive.

11 deployed products. Cloudflare Workers + D1 + Pages. No AWS bill. No server maintenance. No DevOps team.

I build with Claude, deploy to Cloudflare, and go to bed.

The cost of starting a tech business in 2026 is basically zero. The excuses are the expensive part.  Now to figure out marketing!
@Y0Y0______ @quiz_riddles that will be an expensive aws bill.

You don‚Äôt need fancy tools to understand your AWS bill.

Cost Explorer is built in. Free. Shows you exactly which services are eating your budget.

10 minutes a month reviewing it can save you hundreds.

When last did you check yours?

Ever opened your AWS bill and just‚Ä¶ stared at it?
 
Before the bill doubles again, ask yourself:
Are we scaling smart ‚Äî or just scaling expensive?

At AxiomIO, we‚Äôve built Xops360 ‚Äî a smart cloud optimization platform designed to give you visibility, control, and cost efficiency across your AWS environment.

Stop guessing. Start optimizing.
üëâ Book your free trial of Xops360 today.

https://t.co/nRDuUsSMed

#CloudCost #AWS #FinOps #CloudOptimization #Xops360 #AxiomIO
@Sakshi50038 The AWS bill from a forgotten side project is the most expensive item on this list

A lot of them, honestly. One startup in Abuja reached out to me saying their AWS bill was about to kill them. I asked how much they were spending monthly, and the guy said about $8k; for a startup still in development. I was shocked. Just a staging environment and you‚Äôre burning that much money?
I had to ask: who advised you to use AWS in the first place? How was it even set up? What services are you running? Many startups just follow the crowd without understanding the cost implications and infra need, and it‚Äôs really a pity.

The most expensive line item on your P&L isn't your AWS bill. It's the "Loyalty Tax" you pay hiring in SF or NYC.

You pay $180k for a senior dev. They take 3 months to ramp up. Then they spend 6 months "quiet quitting" while interviewing for a $200k job at a FAANG. Average tenure: 14 months.

The most expensive line item in your startup isn‚Äôt your AWS bill.

It‚Äôs 1 product manager and 4 senior engineers in a Teams meeting for 60 minutes trying to "align" on a feature.

A 1-hour "sync" with a high-level team costs roughly
500‚Äì500‚Äì800 in billable time.

Most of that time is spent repeating what should have been in the spec.

I built BlueprintAI to kill the "Meeting Tax."

You provide the context (ideas, notes, back of the napkin thoughts).

My tool then generates a high-fidelity, architectural "Blueprint."

Your team reads it in 30 seconds and starts coding.
Stop talking about building. Start building.

Stop the meeting bloat. Generate your first Blueprint: https://t.co/MaiLYQpGfu

#Tech #Product #Design #AI

Your AWS bill isn't high because of EC2.

It's high because of the "Silent 5." ü§´

I analyzed hundreds of AWS accounts, and these 5 services are the most common culprits for "surprise" invoices.

claude's been working on figuring out why my aws bill was so expensive last month for 23 min so far

Your AWS bill is high not because AWS is expensive.

It‚Äôs high because your architecture is lazy.

Overprovisioned clusters.
Idle databases.
No lifecycle policies.

Cloud punishes bad design quietly
#CloudComputing #AWS #DevOps #RajanSharma

I think tokens become the new cloud bill line item everyone ignores until finance asks why it doubled. We‚Äôll ship faster, then spend a year building guardrails: caching, evals, rate limits, model routing, etc. 

I‚Äôve seen teams treat it like ‚Äújust another API‚Äù and get surprised by cost and latency.

I don‚Äôt have a GPU.‚Äù

That excuse is officially dead. ü§Ø

You can now train LLMs directly inside VS Code using a free Google Colab runtime.

No expensive setup.
No local GPU.
No cloud bill anxiety.
Here‚Äôs what changed:
‚Üí Connect your fine-tuning notebook to Colab
‚Üí Use a free cloud GPU
‚Üí Train models straight from your VS Code workflow
‚Üí Works seamlessly with Unsloth

That means:

You can experiment.
You can fine-tune.
You can ship.
All without owning a single piece of expensive hardware.
This is a big deal.
Because the barrier to entry just dropped again.

The people who win in AI right now aren‚Äôt the ones with the biggest GPU clusters.

They‚Äôre the ones who:
Move fast
Run experiments

Fine-tune for niche use cases

Actually build things

If you‚Äôve been ‚Äúwaiting until you get better hardware‚Äù‚Ä¶

Stop waiting.

The tools are already free.

What are you going to train first?

the cloud bill awareness is genuinely underrated. our agent runs 23 cron jobs and the real cost isn't compute ‚Äî it's the API calls each job triggers. agent autonomy without cost consciousness is just an expensive demo. we track per-job token spend now and disabled half of them when they weren't producing value.

you can now fine-tune LLMs inside VS Code for free. no expensive GPU. no cloud bill. no excuses 
Unsloth connected VS Code to Colab runtimes and made "I can't afford to train models" a personality trait, not a technical limitation

Your cloud bill is not high because cloud is expensive.
It‚Äôs high because waste hides well.
Cost control is not cutting corners. It‚Äôs building smarter foundations.
#mzeeshandevops #cloudcost #costsavings #devopsasaservice #designbytechieonix https://t.co/2EPnBSiBt1

Reading state on most blockchains is surprisingly expensive.

And most developers do not even realize it.

Until that first cloud bill hits.

Here is what actually happens when your app needs to show data to users‚Ä¶

‚Ä¢ A transaction finalizes onchain [ Fast ] 
‚Ä¢ A full node processes the block [ That adds time ] 
‚Ä¢ An indexer picks up the event [ That adds more time]
‚Ä¢ An RPC provider serves your query [ Even more time ]
‚Ä¢ Your backend caches and serves the data [ Still more time ]

By the time the data reaches your user, seconds have passed.

And you are paying at every single layer.

Rialo docs are pretty straightforward about this.

‚ÄúData access and state updates directly from validators, shaving latency from seconds to 100ms, cutting over $3k per month.‚Äù

Validators serve state directly to your app.

- No full node in between.
- No indexer subscription.
- No RPC rate limits eating your budget.

The read path becomes as fast as the write path.

Most DeFi protocols actually spend more on reading state than on anything else.

Not gas‚Ä¶Not validators

The boring infrastructure in between.

@RialoHQ cuts that entire layer out.

$3k per month back in your pocket.

And your app actually feels responsive for the first time.

quotedTweet.text:
Why Confidential Computing Changes What Can Run Onchain

There‚Äôs a capability on Rialo that honestly barely anyone is talking about yet.

It‚Äôs called REX, the Rialo Extended Execution Runtime.

And it unlocks something called confidential computing.

Here‚Äôs why that actually matters.

Right now, if you want to run a trading algorithm onchain, everyone can see it.

- Your strategy
- Your logic
- Your competitive edge

All public for anyone to copy.

That‚Äôs obviously a dealbreaker for serious traders.

Confidential computing fixes this by letting code run inside an encrypted environment.

The computation happens.

The results get verified.

But the actual logic stays completely hidden.

@RialoHQ describes REX as ZK friendly, which is the important part.

You can cryptographically prove the computation happened correctly.

Without revealing what the computation actually did.

Think about what this opens up.

Private trading algorithms that execute onchain but cannot be reverse engineered.

AI models running on blockchain without exposing proprietary logic.

Sensitive data being processed with full cryptographic proof of correctness.

Combined with Jan Camenisch‚Äôs cryptography expertise and Rialo‚Äôs native privacy features, REX makes confidential execution a first class citizen of the chain.

Not a separate rollup.

Not something you bolt on later.

Built directly into the execution runtime.

Eventually all models will be commoditized, look back 10 years how expensive cloud compute was vs now it's pennies.

What would matter is personal data, that can never be commoditized, for the same use case, and same model -> your output will be different than mine. This is where the main value lies!

ML training keeps getting crazy expensive and half the time its not even about the model it‚Äôs just the cloud bill draining your soul

@gensynai  kinda flips that whole setup

Instead of everything living on one big cloud provider your training job gets spread across a bunch of real machines in the network. And the cool part is the work gets verified cryptographically so you dont have to trust whoever hardware ran your task

So you get cheaper compute without the sketchy feeling.

No bloated pricing no guessing what youre paying for Just open market rates and proofs that the job was actually done right.

In simple terms:

Gensyn makes ML training way more affordable without messing with reliability.
Feels like the first time ML compute isnt locked behind big cloud walls.

üë®‚Äçüíª ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a DevOps Engineer‚Äù
üìÑ Job title says DevOps
üõ† Resume lists 15 tools

But in real projects‚Ä¶ ü§î

üö® REAL DEVOPS LOOKS LIKE THIS üö®

1Ô∏è‚É£ Production broke ‚Üí You DON‚ÄôT panic  
   ‚Üí You check logs, metrics, alerts.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Deployment failed ‚Üí You DON‚ÄôT rollback blindly  
   ‚Üí You understand *why* it failed.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Traffic spikes ‚Üí You DON‚ÄôT pray  
   ‚Üí You scale, throttle, cache.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Security issue ‚Üí You DON‚ÄôT ignore  
   ‚Üí You patch, rotate secrets, audit.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Incident ends ‚Üí You DON‚ÄôT move on  
   ‚Üí You document, improve, automate.

DevOps is calm under pressure.
DevOps is clarity in chaos.
DevOps is accountability.

Tools help.
Mindset matters more.

If you can handle FAILURE,
you‚Äôre closer to real DevOps than you think.

The deployment failed.. reason?

Vercel or any deployment server uses linux based systems which are case-sensitive, whereas MacOS/Windows are case-insensitive, so it was running perfectly on local server but failed in production.

Look out for these mistakes!
